lines.text: Jeff, has it ever occurred to you that this is none of your business?
It's none of my business when I see a dog being whipped, but I'll stop it every time.
She came here for reasons you couldn't even spell.
I could make a fire by rubbing two boy scouts together.
I wish a man would marry me so I could wear a decent hat.
That's the best reason for getting married I ever heard.
Oh, I want to go to the bachelor dinner.
Can you do a fan dance?
I invented the fan dance.
I saw one with electric fans once, it was awful
I wish I were a man.
Were, or had?

[as he helps Paula pick up the Dining table and carry it]
Where are we going?
To Cairo, where do you think, we're going to the Kitchen.
Come on, Shemp, my boy. We've only got one night to do a week's drinking.
Connie, I need to speak to you.
But darling, I'm learning to tap dance!
This is more important than tap dancing!
Just look at those cornflowers... When I was a kid, I said I wanted to be married in a cornflower dress. Dill remembered. Married in hundreds of cornflowers. What a perfect wedding.
It's a matter of taste. I'd just soon be married in alcohol.
Eleanor!
Oh, now, don't worry, Paula. I'll be so old they'll have to pickle me in something!
Don't be silly. I'm not going to faint. I'm not the type.

[Bursting into room, seeing Mary getting a massage]
Mary! How can you let yourself be pounded with your wedding less than twenty-four hours off?
Early to bed, early to rise, makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise.
You ever look at a milkman?
Oo-ouch! Ouch! Hey, Bella, I'm going to need that leg to get married with tomorrow.
What you say?
The bride was vision of beauty in black and blue spots. Now, wouldn't that be pretty?
Black and blue, green or yellow, you are a sucker to get married.
Say, is that an attack on my future husband or are you just anti-wedding?
Both.
Are you through?
Yeah.
I wish you'd take your thumb out of my back.
Hey, Paula. What goes on at bachelor dinners?
As I understand it, very little, goes on.
I get it.
Shemp, you know Spain's fine; but, I hope I never go back. You know, when that Statue of Liberty waved at me, she positively had sex with me.

Two years of it. Work, work, work, all day long. And at night, a nice peaceful quiet Spain. Boy, but now that I'm home and all of that lovely Brooklyn noise, baby, I'm gonna stay here. New York! What a town! Hard, cold, unfriendly, everything bad. But, baby, I love it! You know, when I got a look at that skyline today, baby, I'm telling you, I got a thrill like I've never had in my life before. The Woolworth's building. The Chrysler building. Oh, babe! Hey, taxi, taxi!
Tell me Jeff, how was Spain? Full of Spaniards?
Did you wear your rubbers? I understand it rains for months, at a time, in Spain.
Darling, I lived in Madrid. It's like Paris.
Oh really, I understood it's quite savage, jungles and things.
Paula's never read Ernest Hemmingway.
Evidently not.
Come on, let's get out of here. I've got to go drink myself into proper condition to give the bride away.
I got just the drink. You take a jigger of brandy, a pony of rye, three fingers of vodka, a dash of radium and stand well back.
How do I know you've stopped?
Because, I'm licked.
Well, if you're awake, why don't you open your eyes?
I can't. I' afraid they'll drop out.
We went to a bachelor dinner last night. He ate too much ice cream
We better find him somehow. After all, the wedding starts in a couple of hours and we've got to find somebody to marry Mary. Marry Mary? Marry Mary! That's right!
You know, between the two of us, we managed to get one man undressed.
She worries more about something to worry about than she worries about an actual worry.

[Disapprovingly]
What is that smell? Fresh air?
After all, Mrs. Todd, I've known Dill much longer than you have and, well, we had a few things we wanted to talk over.
Dill doesn't talk with his hands.
Really? Isn't that funny, he always used to.

[Speaking to Dill's new wife, Connie]
Yes, yes, but, please hear my story. You know, I started life in the service of Mary's grandfather, one Colonel Lionel Q. Clay, of the Confederate army.
Union army.
Confederate.
Union army.
Confederate.
I beg your pardon, Union army.
I was, at that time, a colored slave and very anxious for the South to win, so I could collect my back pay. I'm still trying to collect.

[Sarcastically]
How dare you say that! We once paid you a dollar eighty on account.

Jeff, stop talking like a big noble brother! Will you get it through your head that I'm free, white and twenty-one! And if I want to, I'll keep my self-respect around until its lost! I've played according to the book from now and where am I? From now on I use my own rules!
Just as soon as I can arrange my business, I'm going back to Spain and get into a nice, quiet, revolution!
